descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: There are infinite ways in which a living system could represent and interact with its surroundings. Homo sapiens have converged upon a very specific set of representations and behaviors. In this course, students will learn how and why we conceptualize objects, events, and people in the ways we do. Moreover, they will discover how do our capacities to represent, understand and interact with various aspects of our world change over time as a function of intricate interactions between nature and nurture. Topics include biology and behavior, infancy, cognitive and social development, language and conceptual development, emotional and self development, the role of family and peers, and adolescence. While the course will cover human development from the moment of conception to old age, there will be an emphasis on early childhood. In addition to learning the methodologies and theoretical frameworks that developmental scientists use to understand the mind, students will be able to contextualize contemporary developmental psychology within millennia-old philosophical questions. Carries social science credit:

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course you will be able to:
-Describe the current scientific knowledge on human psychological development
-Distinguish methodologies that have revealed the way the mind works and how it changes throughout development
-Contextualize the current understanding of human psychological development within current and historical theories
-Scientifically identify of developmental themes in everyday life
-Evaluate several philosophical stances on developmental and evolutionary themes
